posts.post_content: Alright, my opponent's creature can't attack . . . oh wait, he just pumped it with a beneficial spell, destroyed the enchantment, and screwed up my plan to kill him. This card is appalling; in no way, shape, or form does this card capture the mechanic or flavor of blue. Honestly, I'm disappointed.

Posted By: PrizedUnicorn (7/16/2009 11:42:21 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Comparing Oblivion Ring to Ice Cage is somewhat illogical. Oblivion Ring is white and three costing. What about mono-blue decks? What if you need a *two* costing card to disable a blocking/attacking creature?   
  
Saying this card is garbage is not only illogical, but ridiculous, because you fail to provide any reason for your statement and take account of special cir\*\*\*stances. If you get your kicks by trash-talking cards, go talk about Squire, not Ice Cage.  
  
I give Ice Cage a 3. Getting rid of the card via abilities uses up an opponents ability on one of his or her own creatures, so that's not a terrible drawback in most situations. The card itself is a little more flexible than it's white counterpart, Pacifism, which makes it feel a little more blue. *If you base your whole game plan on Ice Cage crippling your enemy and winning the game*, its going to disappoint you. If you need a solid blue card to stop a pesky creature for a couple of turns, its a good card for two.

The card itself is a little more flexible than it's white counterpart, Pacifism, which makes it feel a little more blue. If you base your whole game plan on Ice Cage crippling your enemy and winning the game, its going to disappoint you. If you need a solid blue card to stop a pesky creature for a couple of turns, its a good card for two.

Posted By: Beargh (8/2/2009 10:18:22 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: This card is pretty good. I used to play mono-white before going mono-blue, and honestly, I find it to be a good tradeoff. Sure, the opponent can easily eliminate the hold, but played early, it's great! Plus, it works with blue's mantra: low cost trip-up spells. Look at Essence Scatter and Negate. They cost the same. This card's use is incapacitating a creature you couldn't catch with either of those and opening the opponent to attack. Of course, I prefer to use Unsummon, but that's just personal preference.
posts.html:

posts.post_content: A poor man's [Pacifism](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pacifism) - more easily gotten rid of, but stopping abilities is definitely useful. If, by some chance, your opponent's deck doesn't have anything that targets (unlikely, but possible), then you're in reasonably good shape, but otherwise, BOO.

Posted By: RobinHood3000 (8/6/2009 6:40:47 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This just came to me with this card. Say you were playing a creature card with a static ability like Magus of the Moon (I know he's red but its the only card that I can think of at the moment). Anyway, when a card like that comes into play you would want to protect him in some way. Well, his ability has already been activated, so could you not cast Ice Cage on him to protect him?
  
   
I just got back into playing after a long hiatus so this might not be legal, but I can't see why it wouldn't be. In my opinion that makes this a pretty good card.
posts.html:

Posted By: gellar76 (8/14/2009 1:23:40 PM)
Rating:

Oblivion Ring is still far superior to this card. First of all, Oblivion Ring can target any nonland permanent (including Planeswalkers), not just creatures. Second, for an opponent to get his creature back, he has to take out the ring, not just pump his own creature.

@gellar76:
It seems that you are imagining that if the enchanted creature would be destroyed, destroy Ice Cage instead, which isn't the case at all. Ice Cage does nothing to protect creatures from removal. It is fragile removal in itself; nothing more.
Report Abuse

posts.post_content: This card really should read, "If creature is dealt damage, destroy Ice Cage." Would make a lot more sense, considering the cage being made out of ice and all (and a Volcanic Fallout or Firespout would result in said cage being melted).
